column1: lukealive 159428987451 "2017-04-10 22:05:58 GMT" http://lukealive.tumblr.com/post/159428987451/authorities-reportedly-detaining-and-killing-gay "sullengirlalmlghty: sullengirlalmlghty:   More than 100 gay men have been detained â€œin connection with their nontraditional sexual orientation
column2: or suspicion of such
column3: â€ according to the New York Times
column4: which cites the opposition newspaper Novaya Gazeta. The Russian newspaper says it confirmed the news with government officials and an analyst of the region also confirmed the news to the Times with her own sources. Three men are known to have been murdered
column5: although the real number is likely to be higher.  in almost every genocide
column6: the firstÂ â€œactâ€ is the rounding up and killing of a group of men
column7: specifically.  In â€œroot and branchâ€ genocides they [â€civilian men of â€˜battle ageâ€™â€] are often the first group to be separated out and massacred
column8: paving the way for the murder of women
column10: and elderly men. In more common articulations of genocide
column12: they can be the only group slated for outright massacre
column15: and elderly men suffer a range of alternative fates involving rape
column20: and expulsion. Gender and the Future of Genocide Studies and PreventionÂ   as the rest of this article explains this isnâ€™t to say that men have it worst in a genocide
column21: but that itâ€™s important when you see a very common red flag for genocide to pay attention to theÂ â€œconflictâ€ in case any more markers of an impending genocide occur.Â  the g word is really loaded and iâ€™m not bringing this up because i want to start an avalanche ofÂ â€œCHECHNYA IS COMMITTING GENOCIDE AGAINST GAY PEOPLEâ€ fear mongering (that is the absolute last thing that i want). itâ€™s just not possible to prevent any genocide without questioning whether a current conflict might eventually get there. and i do not think itâ€™s nothing that genocide watch is reporting on this.  UPDATE 4/10/17 Chechnya has opened concentration camps for gay men   Gay men arrested in a â€˜purgeâ€™ in the Russian region of Chechnya are being held in concentration camp-style prisons
column22: reports have alleged. Early reports emerged earlier this month that gay people are being targeted in the region
column23: which is part of Russia but has substantial autonomy. Russian newspapers and human rights groups report that more than 100 gay men have been detained â€œin connection with their non-traditional sexual orientation
column24: or suspicion of suchâ€ as part of a purge. Several people were also reportedly feared dead following violent raids. In a chilling response
column25: a Chechen government spokesperson denied that there are any gay people to detain
column26: insisting that â€œyou canâ€™t detain and harass someone who doesnâ€™t exist in the republicâ€. The Kremlin denied any knowledge of a purge. But reports have since emerged that the men arrested are being kept in horrific concentration camp prisons
column27: where violent abuse and torture is common. Based on interviews with eyewitnesses and survivors
column28: Novaya Gazeta reports that a secret prison has been set up in the town of Argun to detain the men arrested in the purge. One man who was released from the camp told the newspaper that he was subjected to violent â€œinterrogationsâ€ at the camp
column29: as Chechen officials attempted to get him to confess the names and locations of more gay men. The officials also seized his mobile phone
column30: targeting his network of contacts regardless of whether they were gay or not. The camp was reportedly set up by Chechen forces in a former military headquarters in the town. The newspaper reports allegations that the Speaker of the Parliament of Chechnya was among officials to visit the site
column31: though the claims have not been substantiated. The detainees face electric shock torture and violent beatings
column32: while some of them have been held to ransom and used to extort their families. Tanya Lokshina of Human Rights Watch wrote: â€œFor several weeks now
column33: a brutal campaign against LGBT people has been sweeping through Chechnya. She continued: â€œLaw enforcement and security agency officials under control of the ruthless head of the Chechen Republic
column35: have rounded up dozens of men on suspicion of being gay
column36: torturing and humiliating the victims. â€œSome of the men have forcibly disappeared. Others were returned to their families barely alive from beatings. At least three men apparently have died since this brutal campaign began.â€ She added: â€œThese days
column37: very few people in Chechnya dare speak to human rights monitors or journalists even anonymously because the climate of fear is overwhelming and people have been largely intimidated into silence. â€œFiling an official complaint against local security officials is extremely dangerous
column38: as retaliation by local authorities is practically inevitable. â€œIt is difficult to overstate just how vulnerable LGBT people are in Chechnya
column39: where homophobia is intense and rampant. â€œLGBT people are in danger not only of persecution by the authorities but also of falling victim to â€˜honour killingsâ€™ by their own relatives for tarnishing family honour.â€ What Can We Do?   Alexander Artmyev from Amnesty International spoke to Metro.co.uk. He said that people who are not in Russia can help by joining the charityâ€™s Urgent Action on Chechnya. The action encourages people to write in Russian or your own language to Chairman of the Investigation Committee and Acting Head of the Investigation Committee for the Chechen Republic. Amnesty has also asked the letter
column40: which should ask for an investigation and appeal for protection for LGBT individuals
column41: to be copied into Human Rights groups and diplomatic missions from your country. " False link

column1: lukealive 155812815451 "2017-01-13 17:13:15 GMT" http://lukealive.tumblr.com/post/155812815451/the-rise-of-the-working-poor-and-the-non-working "riotrite:  robertcmmacgregor:  Many believe that poor people deserve to be poor because theyâ€™re lazy. As Speaker John Boehner has said
column2: the poor have a notion that â€œI really donâ€™t have to work. I donâ€™t really want to do this. I think Iâ€™d rather just sit around.â€ In  reality
column3: a large and growing share of the nationâ€™s poor work full time  â€“ sometimes sixty or more hours a week â€“ yet still donâ€™t earn enough  to lift themselves and their families out of poverty.   Itâ€™s also commonly believed
column5: that the rich deserve their wealth because they work harder than others.  In reality
column6: a large and growing portion of the super-rich have never broken a sweat. Their wealth has been handed to them.  The  rise of these two groups â€“ the working poor and non-working rich â€“ is  relatively new. Both are challenging the core American assumptions that  people are paid what theyâ€™re worth
column7: and work is justly rewarded. Why are these two groups growing? The ranks of the working poor are growing because wages at the bottom have dropped
column8: adjusted for inflation. With increasing numbers of Americans taking  low-paying jobs in retail sales
column15: the pay of the  bottom fifth is falling closer to the minimum wage. At the same time
column16: the real value of the federal minimum wage is lower today than it was a quarter century ago.  In addition
column17: most recipients of public assistance must now work in order to qualify.  Bill  Clintonâ€™s welfare reform of 1996 pushed the poor off welfare and into  work. Meanwhile
column20: has  emerged as the nationâ€™s largest anti-poverty program. Here
column22: having a  job is a prerequisite.  The new work requirements havenâ€™t reduced  the number or percentage of Americans in poverty. Theyâ€™ve just moved  poor people from being unemployed and impoverished to being employed and  impoverished. A very clever scheme by Republicans. While poverty declined in the early years of  welfare reform when the economy boomed and jobs were plentiful
column23: it began  growing in 2000. By 2012 it exceeded its level in 1996
column24: when welfare ended. At  the same time
column25: the ranks of the non-working rich have been swelling.  Americaâ€™s legendary â€œself-madeâ€ men and women are fast being replaced by  wealthy heirs.  Six of todayâ€™s ten wealthiest Americans are heirs  to prominent fortunes. The Walmart heirs alone have more wealth than  the bottom 40 percent of Americans combined. Americans  who became enormously wealthy over the last three decades are now  busily transferring that wealth to their children and grand children. The nation is on the cusp of the largest inter-generational transfer of wealth in history. A study  from the Boston College Center on Wealth and Philanthropy projects a  total of $59 trillion passed down to heirs between 2007 and 2061. As  the French economist Thomas Piketty reminds us
column26: this is the kind of  dynastic wealth thatâ€™s kept Europeâ€™s aristocracy going for centuries.  Itâ€™s about to become the major source of income for a new American  aristocracy. This is what the Koch/Walton Republicans have schemed for; the Gilded Age. The tax code encourages all this by favoring unearned income over earned income.  The  top tax rate paid by Americaâ€™s wealthy on their capital gains â€“ the  major source of income for the non-working rich â€“ has dropped from 33  percent in the late 1980s to 20 percent today
column27: putting it substantially  below the top tax rate on ordinary income (36.9 percent). If the owners of capital assets whose worth increases over their lifetime hold them until death
column28: their heirs pay zero capital gains taxes on them. Such â€œunrealizedâ€ gains now account for more than half the value of assets held by estates worth more than $100 million. At  the same time
column29: the estate tax has been slashed. Before George W. Bush  was president
column30: it applied to assets in excess of $2 million per couple  at a rate of 55 percent. Now it kicks in at $10
column33: at a  40 percent rate. Last year only 1.4 out of every 1
column35: and the effective rate they paid was only 17 percent. Republicans  now in control of Congress want to go even further. Last Friday the  Senate voted 54-46 in favor of a non-binding resolution to repeal the  estate tax altogether. Earlier in the week
column36: the House Ways and Means  Committee also voted for a repeal. The House is expected to vote in  coming weeks. Yet the specter of an entire generation doing  nothing for their money other than speed-dialing their wealth management  advisers is not particularly attractive. It puts more and more  responsibility for investing a substantial portion of the nationâ€™s  assets into the hands of people who have never worked. It also endangers our democracy
column37: as dynastic wealth inevitably and invariably accumulates political influence and power. Consider  the rise of both the working poor and the non-working rich
column38: and the  meritocratic ideal on which Americaâ€™s growing inequality is often  justified doesnâ€™t hold up. That widening inequality â€“ combined  with the increasing numbers of people who work full time but are still  impoverished and of others who have never worked and are fabulously  wealthy â€“ is undermining the moral foundations of American capitalism.
